p:
Due to the broad technological applications of beryllium oxocompounds
1– 3 , their structure and chemical bonding became a focus of a number of recent experimental and theoretical studies. Small atomic radius and high ionization energy of beryllium make covalent interactions playing the important role in stabilizing beryllium compounds, unlike other alkaline-earth elements. In contrast to MgO, CaO, SrO, and BaO, at ambient conditions BeO crystallizes in the hexagonal wurtzite structure, featuring tetrahedrally coordinated Be 2+ and O 2− ions
4 . Bonding of beryllium to four oxygen atoms with the formation of BeO 4 6 − tetrahedra is also exclusive for its natural occurrence
5 . Various molecular oxygen-rich composition compounds (BeO 2, Be 2O 2, Be 2O 4, BeO 4, and Be(O 3) 2) demonstrating diverse Be–O bonding situations have been recently isolated within solid noble-gas matrices
6 . Cases with Be in coordination higher than four have not been observed experimentally for inorganic compounds, though recent ab initio calculation studies on BeO 2
7 and BeO
8 have predicted the formation of BeO 6 octahedra with ionic Be–O bonding at high pressures.
